justification: The article states that in the ‘description’ trials of the choice task, “participants traded off described risk (the probability of reward) and money,” indicating that the described-risk choice task was used to quantify how participants prefer or avoid risk.

For the ‘motor’ trials the authors note that “participants traded off risk derived from sensori-motor experience … and money,” showing that the sensori-motor version of the choice task served as a behavioural measure of risk preference.

In introducing BART the paper explains that it “involves trading off risk and reward… participants’ goal is to maximize earnings by inflating virtual balloons,” confirming that BART was employed to assess individuals’ risk-taking tendencies.

measured_by: Prospect Theory parameter γ estimated from choice data
justification: The Methods section states that Prospect Theory was fit as a measurement model and that “Prospect Theory describes the role of risk and reward… with two parameters (α, γ),” where γ captures how probabilities are psychologically weighted.

measured_by: Prospect Theory parameter α estimated from choice data
justification: The same model-fitting description specifies that parameter α in Prospect Theory reflects the value (utility) function for money, thereby providing a quantitative measure of participants’ sensitivity to monetary outcomes.
